The California Supreme Court just ruled that the gay weddings performed in San Francisco are void. I'm not surprised, and I even think it was the right decision. The mayor's heart was in the right place, but we can not allow local officials to ignore the law. He could have used his clout as the mayor of SF to help gay couples sue the state to change the law against gay marriage. Instead he flouted the law, and now thousands of couples that were married aren't any longer. Maybe he just didn't want to be upstaged by Massachusettes, but whatever his reasons, he went about things the wrong way.
I'm glad lawlessness didn't prevail there.

 I think the same thing happened in Seattle. A local judge said that he was going to allow same-sex marriages. It is not their authority to do that.

Here's the court's ruling, for those who like that sort of thing.
 
 http://news.findlaw.com/cnn/docs/glrts/lckyrsf81204opn.pdf
 
 A quick glance gave me the impression that the gist of it is, city officials aren't supposed to break the law.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Gay marriage in SF
